statement.tex: \text{Prove that the function }\\ \quad f(x) = \log\cos x \\ \text{is strictly decreasing on }\left(0,\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\\ \text{and strictly increasing on }\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},0\right)

step.context: \text{Can }f(x)\text{ be increasing over }\left(\frac{\pi}{2},\pi\right)\\ \text{as asked in the textbook}?
step.tex: \text{No. In fact, }\log\cos x\text{ is not even }\\ \text{defined in }\left(\frac{\pi}{2},\pi\right)\text{ because }\\ \cos x\lt 0\text{ when }x\in\left(\frac{\pi}{2},\pi\right).
\text{Yes, sure. Why not?} \\ \text{Its in textbook, right?}
step.reason: \log x \text{ makes sense only if }x\gt 0.\\ \therefore \log\cos x\text{ makes sense only when }\cos x\gt 0\\ \implies x\in \left(-\frac{\pi}{2},\frac{\pi}{2}\right).
f'(x) = -\tan x\implies f'(x)\gt 0\text{ when }\tan x\lt 0\\ \text{(fourth quadrant) and }f'(x)\lt 0\implies\tan x\gt 0\\ \text{ (first quadrant)}.
